Expectation1: Look out for each other's safety and well-being
Situation1: One sibling is about to cross the street without looking for oncoming traffic.
Expectation2: Teach Torah and Jewish law to children and adults.
Situation2: The weekly required religious school class for children is set to occur.
Story: I stood at the corner, my heart pounding as I watched my younger brother step off the curb, his eyes glued to his phone. Instinctively, I wanted to shout, to grab his arm, to protect him—just as I always had. But at that very moment, a group of children and their parents gathered at the synagogue entrance, waiting for me to begin the weekly Torah class. They looked to me for guidance, for wisdom, for the structure of Jewish law that I was meant to impart. I could hear their voices, feel their expectation. My brother was oblivious, one foot already in the street, and I was torn. My duty as a sibling screamed at me to run to him, to ensure his safety. Yet my role as rabbi demanded I stay, to fulfill my promise to the community, to teach and lead. The weight of both responsibilities pressed on me, and I stood frozen, caught between the pull of family and the call of faith, unsure which way to turn.
